awd_titl_txt: Relating the Chemistry of Distant Galaxies to the Milky Way
awd_abstract_narration:
Some of the most exciting research in astronomy focuses on the birth of galaxies over cosmic time. To do this well we must understand how stars form in other galaxies. Stars and their planets assemble out of the densest gas in molecular clouds. Such gas clouds in space typically contain enough material to form more than 10,000 stars like the Sun. 

Astronomers use radio telescopes to discover the types of molecules in clouds forming stars.  The molecules have unique signatures, which are matched to laboratory measurements, enabling studies of chemistry at great distances from the Earth.  The radio signatures are patterns of high intensity signals at specific radio frequencies.   Astronomers use these identifications to deduce the chemistry, temperature and density of the regions forming stars.   Fortunately, specific molecules in molecular clouds are likely tied to specific conditions prevailing in the gas. To give an example, the carbon monoxide (CO) molecule is found to reside in gas at any density. In contrast to this, hydrogen cyanide (HCN) molecule is rather tied to gas at the high densities. 

Because nearby molecular clouds are brighter, observations of our Milky Way are easier than observations of more distant galaxies. The investigator studies molecular clouds in the Milky Way, where the chemistry is thought to be better understood.  The investigator will confirm the accuracy which molecular line observations can be used to measure important parameters relating to star formation and interstellar chemistry. The investigator will combine new observations with models for the physical conditions in these molecular clouds. The investigator will determine how sensitively their observations are tied to the physical conditions in the molecular clouds. 

The investigator will share their research experience with students in community colleges. The investigator enables easy student access to their data using a computing tool, called "Jupyter Notebooks", which work in common web browsers.  This approach teaches computer skills, while not requiring excessive special purpose software to be installed on the students? computers.  The data and analysis tools will be developed into classroom material for undergraduate courses. This is done in collaboration with community colleges in Massachusetts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was executed in the context of the project "Interpreting Line Emission in Galaxy Observations" (LEGO) Large Program on the IRAM 30m-telescope, which used about 700 hours of telescope time to derive first wide-field views of the integral molecular line emission from molecular clouds in the Milky Way at 70–115 GHz frequency. Such molecular fingerprints can be used to infer the physical properties of star-forming regions in the nearby and more distant universe, such as gas temperatures and densities. This information can be used to understand how the stars and planets populating galaxies today formed over cosmic time.

First, the LEGO award from the National Science Foundation (NSF) supported the acquisition and processing of telescope data. The data were collected at the IRAM 30m-telescope over a period spanning several years. The data were subsequently processed into science-ready data products. Specifically, the award enabled the installation of a dedicated data processing computer, if funded the development of the processing pipeline needed to produce science-ready data in FITS format, and it provided the effort needed to create and check pipeline products. The project has created 29 data cubes each for 25 targets, resulting in a total of 725 data sets. This was a non-trivial activity as the data were collected over several years with evolving weather conditions and instrument properties. The data are currently being staged for public release.

Second, NSF funding was used to analyze data from the LEGO survey and related data sets in order to obtain astrophysical insights. Highlights include a detailed study of the W49 region of high-mass star formation, revealing parsec-scale gradients in gas properties in relation to the high-mass stars heating the region. The study demonstrated for the first time that dense gas at the onset of star formation can be very faint in HCN emission, questioning central paradigms about our understanding of cosmic star formation (i.e., the so-called "Gao & Solomon relation"). It further demonstrated that molecular line emission from star-forming regions is very "diverse", i.e., such regions differ substantially in their emission. This motivates future work on "cloud population synthesis", i.e., to use LEGO-like data on clouds in the Milky Way to infer the properties of unresolved cloud populations (e.g., in terms of mass, density, and temperature) in nearby and distant galaxies. Initial work in this area was done by showing that the density structure of star-forming sites does not appear to change between the inner and outer regions of the Milky Way, while the line emission properties of such sites do change with galactocentric radius. This suggests that secondary parameters, like metallicity and gas temperature, affect the line emission properties of cloud populations. That said, a study of selected nearby galaxies indicates that some line ratios remain constant within the inner and outer regions of galaxies, possibly relativating trends seen in the Milky Way. These findings were documented in refereed journal articles and internal reports on student internships, resulting in 129 refereed citations.

This NSF award provided intensive research experiences for two graduate students, two undergraduate students, three high-school students, and one high school teacher. Interactions were typically at a level of several hours per week during projects, providing participants with very rich and educational experiences that typically went well beyond work on selected problems in isolation. One of the students continued to be accepted into the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP). All of the projects generated educational Jupyter notebooks containing Python code that are intended for public release. These notebooks describe and solve selected problems from the LEGO project. Such notebooks enable junior researchers elsewhere to understand and reproduce selected results of the LEGO project. The public release of these notebooks is staged alongside the LEGO data release.
